newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakh c.bank issues notes amid pension payoff.
newsitem.headline: Kazakh c.bank issues notes amid pension payoff.

text.p: Kazakhstan's National Bank said on Tuesday it would issue 56-day notes to sterilise more money in circulation and avoid a rise in inflationary pressures as it conducts a significant pay-off of pension arrears.
"The launch of 56-day notes is certainly connected with the pay-off of pension arrears," a senior National Bank official told Reuters.
A bank statement said the first auction of the new notes worth 800 million tenge ($10.6 million) would be on July 30.
The bank regularly issues seven-, 14- and 28-day notes to sterilise excess cash in circulation and support the national tenge currency.
But government pledges to pay off by January 1 large debts to the former Soviet state's pensioners reaching the equivalent of $480 million mean more cash is to flow into circulation.
Officials in the resource-rich Central Asian state populated by 16.7 million people have repeatedly sought to dispel fears of an inflationary uptrend which may be linked to the pay-off.
Prices grew by 6.7 percent in the first half of this year, well in line with the official target of 17-percent inflation for 1997.
The national tenge currency has been stable at around 75 per dollar since January.
Dealers and economists have said they were not sure where the money paid to pensioners would eventually go -- to the real sector of the economy or into speculative trading.
